title: What is CBT?
introduction: Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT) is an evidence-based approach that links thoughts, feelings, and actions. By spotting common thinking traps—such as catastrophising, mind-reading, or "all-or-nothing" statements—you can practise kinder, more balanced perspectives.

whyHelpsAvpd.title: Why it helps with AvPD
whyHelpsAvpd.description: People living with Avoidant Personality Disorder often battle intense self-criticism and fear of negative evaluation. CBT offers practical tools to:
tools: Name unhelpful thoughts rather than accept them as facts.
Test those thoughts against real-world evidence.
Practise alternative interpretations in small, safe steps.
whyHelpsAvpd.conclusion: Consistent CBT exercises can gradually chip away at the belief "I will always be rejected."

howWeUse.title: How re-frame uses CBT
howWeUse.description: When you describe a situation, re-frame highlights likely thinking traps and suggests gentler viewpoints. You remain in control—choose what feels true and helpful, discard the rest.

reminder.text: re-frame is a self-help companion, not a substitute for professional care. If you feel unsafe with your thoughts, please reach out to a qualified therapist or crisis line.
